ygData.subject: Re: Spatial & connective CPPNs for Alife domains
ygData.msgSnippet: I am not using bias node/s for two reasons. One is that I can t find a meaningful position for them. The second is that I am going to use leaky-integrators.

I am not using bias node/s for two reasons. One is that I can't find 
a mea=
ningful position for them. The second is that I am going to use 
leaky-inte=
grators. Bias inputs are not well suited for them. I let 
the CPPN output t=
he time constants and bias instead. 
I constrain the experiment to 2D for s=
implicity. If it proves to be 
interesting, I will extend to 3D easily. Thi=
s will bump up the 
dimentionality of the CPPN input/output space, though. =


Peter

Peter,
>  
> Yes, I believe this is a powerful idea.  In effect the 
pertur=
bations need
> not be a collision, although that analogy works, but can be =
an 
output from
> other networks.
>  
> There are many things one can do wi=
th an intersection of graph
> thermodynamics (including, Fruchterman-Reingo=
ld, Kamada-Kawai, 
Eades, etc)
> force directed graph layout and artificial=
 neural networks. Why 
limit the
> interaction in 2D, or 3D space?
>  
> Th=
is is a technique I use to model a system network graph in a 
context

other system network graph).  The input, output and bias nodes 
of the
> sy=

and its

> Hi again :) 
=
> 
> I am developing an Alife pet project evolving 2D mass-spring based 
> =
creatures. The fitness function can't exactly be defined, since 
they 
> ca=
n be evolved towards some tasks like "go there" or something. I 
> want to =
briefly describe the details behind it. 
> 
> The same network is used for =
both the body and the nervous system 
of 
> the creature. First the body is=
 built by a spatial CPPN and 
converted 
> to a mass-spring model. There ar=
e several tissues (the CPPN outputs 
> tissue type instead of level of expr=
ession). One type of tissue is 
a 
> sensor tissue, which excites upon coll=
ision. Another type of tissue 
> is a muscle tissue, which contracts the sp=
rings when excited. Like 
a 
> regular bilogical muscle. 
> 
> The key poin=
t is, that after the spatial CPPN builds the body, the 
> same CPPN is then=
 used for HyperNEAT (additional outputs, though), 
to 
> evolve the connect=
ivity of the neural network controlling the body. 
> Inputs are located on =
sensor tissue only. Outputs are located on 
> muscle tissue. Hidden nodes a=
re located on the remaining tissue. 
This 
> is essentially evolving both t=
he substrate and the connectivity of 
> the network, but in a meaningful wa=
y, because of the geometry and 
the 
> simulated 2D physics space. 
> 
> Th=
e simulation is like this - when the sensor tissue is excited by 
> some co=
llision, this also plugs 1.0 into the associated HyperNEAT's 
> network's i=
nputs. When the outputs activation level exceeds some 
> treshold, the asso=
ciated springs on the muscle tissue are 
contracted. 
> 
> I believe that u=
sing the same network for both pusposes (spatial 
and 
> connective) is bet=
ter than using different networks. Do you think 
> this in general is a goo=
d idea? 
> 
> Peter
>
